Section Editor            Multiple cranial neuropathies in a
Mitchell S.V. Elkind,
MD, MS                    young man

John C. Probasco, MD      SECTION 1                                                                          on fluid-attenuated inversion recovery images and a
Ashley T. Munchel, MD     A 19-year-old man with no significant medical history                              nonenhancing pineal cyst.
Justin C. McArthur,       noted 3 weeks of right facial numbness and slurred                                 Question for consideration:
   MBBS, MPH              speech. On examination, he had decreased sensation in
Jaishri O. Blakeley, MD   the right middle and lower trigeminal nerve distributions,                         1. What is the differential diagnosis?
                          right tongue deviation, and bilateral facial weakness.                                 In an otherwise healthy young person, diagnostic
                          A lumbar puncture yielded CSF with a lymphocytic                                   considerations would include tumors, demyelinating
Correspondence to         predominant pleocytosis (50 leukocytes/mm3, 95% lym-                               conditions, infectious processes such as CNS borreli-
Dr. Probasco:
jprobas1@jhmi.edu         phocytes), elevated protein (260 mg/dL), and normal                                osis or fungal meningitis, and systemic inflammatory
                          glucose (49 mg/dL), without other evidence of inflam-                              conditions including neurosarcoidosis. A nonen-
                          mation or infection, while serum studies were normal.                              hancing pineal cyst raises concern for a germ cell
                          Brain MRI with gadolinium demonstrated a sub-                                      tumor, pineal parenchymal tumor, and low-grade
                          centimeter left frontal subcortical white matter lesion                            glioma.

                   SECTION 2                                                 Question for consideration:
                  Over 6 months, the patient developed right horizontal     1. What additional tests/studies should be considered?
                  jerking nystagmus, bilateral hearing loss, dysarthria,
                  and dysphagia. Two lumbar punctures demonstrated a            Repeat brain MRI with gadolinium and detailed
                  persistent lymphocytic pleocytosis (37 leukocytes/mm3,    imaging of the midbrain, pons, and medulla; whole-
                  87% lymphocytes, and 60 leukocytes/mm3, 77% lym-          body CT; CSF fungal cultures; CSF acid-fast bacilli
                  phocytes) with elevated protein (197 and 377 mg/dL)       stain and culture; 3 large volume (.30 mL) CSF
                  and elevated glucose (69 and 70 mg/dL) in the CSF with    collections for cytopathology; serum and CSF
                  negative infectious studies and atypical lymphocytes on   a-fetoprotein (aFP); and b-human chorionic gonad-
                  flow cytometrics. Serum studies were unremarkable.        otropin (bHCG).

                     SECTION 3                                                         the bilateral legs. He demonstrated resistance to move-
                    Repeat MRI of the brain with gadolinium demon-                    ment which could be overcome throughout the bilateral
                    strated enhancement of cranial nerves V, VII, IX,                 arms. His reflexes were brisk throughout with plantar
                    X, XI, and the pineal gland cyst. Cervical and thoracic           flexor responses bilaterally. He was well coordinated in
                    spinal MRI was normal. PET demonstrated hyper-                    all extremities except for slow and dysrhythmic left foot
                    plastic marrow but no metastatic disease. He had                  tap. Gait could not be assessed.
                    been treated with a slow oral taper of prednisone,                    Repeat brain MRI with gadolinium (figure 1A)
                    IV glucocorticoids, and IV immunoglobulin (IVIg).                 and dedicated fast imaging employing steady-state
                        On transfer to a tertiary facility, he endorsed dysp-         acquisition series (figure 1B) demonstrated multiple
                    nea, weak cough, difficulty managing secretions, pro-             areas of cranial nerve enhancement, including the
                    gressive weakness in the legs, diminished sensation in            bilateral oculomotor, trigeminal, abducens, facial,
                    the left arm and leg, and 1 month of urinary inconti-             and spinal accessory nerves as well as enhancement
                    nence and constipation. His medications on transfer               of the pineal gland and soft tissue masses in the bilat-
                    were oral prednisone as well as antibiotics for an aspi-          eral trigeminal caves. Spine MRI (figure 1, C and D)
                    ration pneumonia, gastric ulcer prophylaxis, and                  with gadolinium demonstrated multiple focal lesions
                    symptom management for nausea and oral secretions.                within the spinal cord and central canal as well as a
                    There were no notable medical conditions in his fam-              heterogeneously enhancing intradural, extramedul-
                    ily history. He was a high school graduate with no sig-           lary thoracolumbar mass.
                    nificant substance use or travel history.                         Question for consideration:
                        His neurologic examination was remarkable for
                                                                                      1. What is the differential diagnosis for an intradural,
                    visual sensation only for light and movement, fixed
                                                                                         extramedullary spinal cord mass?
                    dilated pupils, downgaze in primary position, upward
                    and lateral eye movement paresis, bilateral ptosis, dimin-            Primary tumor considerations include meningioma,
                    ished bilateral facial sensation, bilateral facial weakness,      schwannoma, neurofibroma, dermoid tumor, and
                    diminished hearing, poor soft palate elevation, weak              lipoma. The differential also includes drop metastases
                    cough, and absent gag reflex. His left leg was externally         of medulloblastoma, ependymoma, glioma, and germ
                    rotated with otherwise antigravity strength throughout            cell tumor.

                      Figure 1       Imaging




                    Repeat MRI with gadolinium of brain demonstrates symmetric enhancement of (A) bilateral trigeminal nerves within trigeminal
                    cave. (B) Fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition series demonstrates enhancement within bilateral cavernous sinuses,
                    bilateral jugular foramen, as well as facial and vestibulocochlear nerves. MRI of thoracolumbar spine (C) T2 and (D) T1 postgado-
                    linium sequences demonstrate heterogeneously enhancing intradural, extramedullary thoracolumbar spinal mass.

                                 bar mass. A lumbar puncture was performed to assay                be disrupted at any site along their course from the
                                 CSF levels of aFP bHCG for comparison to serum                    brainstem to the superficial soft tissues.3 The differential
                                 levels. bHCG levels were elevated in both serum                   diagnosis is extensive, with the patient’s age, immuno-
                                 (1,123 mIU/mL) and CSF (4,104 mIU/mL). aFP lev-                   competence, and tempo of progression all key consider-
                                 els in the CSF (,1 ng/mL) and serum (7 ng/mL) were                ations for clinical evaluation (table 2). The basic
                                 normal. The thoracolumbar mass contained multiple                 evaluation includes assessment for evidence for metabolic
                                 germ cell layers with differentiated tissue (figure 2,            derangements suggestive of systemic processes. Our
                                 A–C). Several OCT-4 and c-kit positive germinoma                  understanding of the etiologies for multiple cranial neu-
                                 cells with focal staining for aFP and bHCG were also              ropathies has been limited to case reports and case series.4
                                 noted (figure 2D).1,2 Final pathologic and oncologic              In the largest series, cancer accounted for 30% of cases.5
                                 diagnosis was immature teratoma with germinoma cells.                 CNS germ cell tumors (GCT) are rare primary brain
                                     He was subsequently transferred to the pediatric              tumors, accounting for 0.6%–3% of all brain tumors,
                                 oncology service and completed the first 2 courses                with an incidence of 0.16 per 100,000 person-years
                                 of induction chemotherapy with carboplatin, etopo-                among pediatric patients 0–19 years of age.6,7 Typically,
                                 side, and ifosfamide prior to transfer to his local med-          CNS GCT present in the second decade of life.7,8 GCT
                                 ical facility. At time of transfer, his serum bHCG was            are broadly classified as germinomatous (composed
                                 markedly reduced (15 mIU/mL). At his local medical                solely of germinoma cells) or non-germinomatous
                                 facility, he completed induction and consolidation                (NGGCT). This distinction is clinically relevant as ger-
                                 chemotherapy. In time, he regained his hearing to a               minomas, like gonadal GCT, are highly curable with
                                 conversational volume, and the ability to partially               5-year survival rates greater than 90%.7–9 In contrast,
                                 open his eyes, speak with partial occlusion of his tra-           NGGCT portend a worse prognosis, with survival of
                                 cheotomy site, and walk with assistance. After 18                 30%–40% with radiation alone. The addition of plat-
                                 weeks of chemotherapy and a prolonged inpatient                   inum-based chemotherapy regimens and surgical resec-
                                 course, he died due to cardiac arrest.                            tion has boosted survival rates in NGGCT to 90% at a
                                                                                                   mean of 96 months.9
                                                                                                       Thought to originate from primitive embryonal cells,
                                 DISCUSSION Multiple cranial neuropathies are com-
                                                                                                   GCT are divided histologically by their resemblance to
                                 mon in neurology, with etiologies ranging from the
                                                                                                   primordial germ cells (germinoma), embryonic differen-
                                                                                                   tiated cells (teratoma), yolk sac endodermal cells (yolk sac
  Figure 2       Histopathology
                                                                                                   tumor), blastocytes (choriocariocarcinoma), or embryo-
                                                                                                   nal pluripotent stem cells (embryonal carcinoma).7,8
                                                                                                   Mixed GCT are composed of various histologic types,
                                                                                                   with the most malignant component determining overall
                                                                                                   prognosis.9
                                                                                                       GCT are classically found in the pineal gland but
                                                                                                   can present anywhere within the CNS. Tumor loca-
                                                                                                   tion governs presenting symptomatology. Patients
                                                                                                   with pineal lesions often present with obstructive
                                                                                                   hydrocephalus and Parinaud syndrome (paralysis of
                                                                                                   upgaze, pupillary light-near dissociation and conver-
                                                                                                   gence-retraction nystagmus).9
                                                                                                       Differentiating between germinomas and NGGCT
                                                                                                   directly influences treatment choices. While there are
                                                                                                   potentially subtle differences in germinomas and
                                                                                                   NGGCT on MRI, imaging alone is not sufficient to
                                                                                                   differentiate between the two.7,8 Biopsy is necessary to
                                                                                                   confirm the diagnosis unless tumor markers are path-
                                                                                                   ognomonic. bHCG and aFP should be checked in
                                                                                                   both serum and CSF if GCT is on the differential.
                                                                                                   While germinomas can secrete low levels of bHCG
Hematoxylin & eosin–stained histopathologic samples from intradural extramedullary tho-
                                                                                                   and aFP, bHCG levels greater than 50 IU/L and
racolumbar mass demonstrate multiple germ cell layers including (A) keratinized skin with
hair follicles, (B) smooth muscle, (C) bronchiolar tissue, and (D) germinoma cells with striated   aFP levels .10 ng/dL in the CSF confirms a diagnosis
muscle.                                                                                            of NGGCT without the need for biopsy, and markedly

                                  markers also serve as a sensitive method to monitor                     We present the case of a young man in his second

   Table 2         Basic evaluation with additional considerations for evaluation of patients with multiple cranial nerve palsies

  Basic initial neurologic imaging:             Additional neurologic imaging to consider:

  CT of head without contrast                   Cavernous sinus syndrome: MRI brain with gadolinium with dedicated series of orbits, CT sinuses/orbits

  Brain MRI with and without gadolinium         Cerebellopontine syndrome: MRI brain with gadolinium with FIESTA dedicated series of the cerebellopontine angle and brainstem

                                                Jugular foramen syndrome: MRA and MRV brain and neck, CTA

                                                Leptomeningeal disease: Total spine MRI with gadolinium

                                                Ischemic/hemorrhagic stroke: GRE/SWI series, MRA or CTA brain and neck, cerebral angiogram

  IgG index (with matched serum IgG)            Histoplasma antigen                                            Fungal antibodies: Aspergillosis,
